No union of sport and media is closer than that between the Olympics and NBC.
NBC has the exclusive American broadcast rights for the Games.
But there's a steep price and an increasingly uncertain payoff.
Its Olympics coverage took the overall ratings crown last night, but it lost in one hour, when it was head to head against the Fox hit American Idol.
NPR's David Folkenflik reports.
NBC wants this winter's Olympics in Turin to sound something like this:
Their coaches said that as partners you live together and die together.
They have been through so much these past six months.
And also like this:
Paul Gardana (ph) won at Lillehammer, and he says he really likes this course because it gives --
But the network must be disappointed its not sounding something more like this:
(Soundbite of cash register)
NBC paid well over $600 million dollars for these Olympics.
The network says more than 170 million Americans have caught sight of the Games on NBC and its sister cable stations.
NBC sports chairman Dick Ebersol predicted this week the network will make more than $50 million dollars in profits.
Paul Swangard is managing director of the Warsaw Sports Marketing Center at the University of Oregon.
For all of NBC's claims, Swangard says it's not clear whether the network will break even.
When the Olympics go away, if people continue to watch NBC and they can entertain that population with other programming, then its $600 million dollars well spent.
If it's another two years until they win a Nielsen week again, I think you begin to question why you spend that much money to win the Nielsen ratings once every two years.
Right now, it's hard to imagine the Olympics without NBC.
The NBC money makes up more than 40 percent of the International Olympics Committee's total budget.
The NBC deal is part of a multi-billion dollar partnership that ensures that it will broadcast the Games through 2012.
NBC's parent company, General Electric, is a global sponsor and a senior executive from NBC Sports sits on the governing board of the International Olympic Committee.
NBC has pushed the for the inclusion of edgier games in the hope of attracting younger viewers, but ratings are down sharply from the Salt Lake City and Nagano Olympics.
Through a spokeswoman, NBC executives declined several requests for comment.
Meanwhile, ABC and Fox have found success by turning conventional wisdom on its ear.
Instead of shying from competition, they broadcast new shows of popular programs, and often beat NBC's Olympic broadcasts.
Carey Cull (ph) is the scheduling czar for CBS.
He says younger viewers in particular are using their remotes.
American Idol has done very well.
Our show, Survivor, has done very well.
Dancing with the Stars has done very well.
Even repeat series like CSI has managed to do very, very well against the Olympics.
That smarts for NBC.
On the plus side, there's been a halo effect for other NBC programs.
The Today Show and the Tonight Show have promoted the Olympics and won more viewers.
Ratings have jumped at cable channels MSNBC and CNBC.
CBS's Cull says his network pursued what he calls a rope-a-dope strategy, keeping new episodes in reserve to try to dominate the spring season.
We didn't really put our strongest foot forward in this sweep because of the Olympics and the Super Bowl.
The sweeps is kind of meant to be a representative month of programming, but with those two events, it was anything but.

American audiences are drawn by United States medal winners, but the University of Oregon's Swangard says the Americans haven't done that well this time around, on the ice, on the slopes, or even on TV.
And he says that's cost NBC viewers.
The Olympics have always been a place where American heroes were made, and that's what's been a compelling draw for consumers for decades.
In a strange sort of way, and in a manufactured sort of way, that's kind of what American Idol is, it manufactures American music heroes.
And Swangard says that a continuing drop in ratings could lead future Olympics to seek inspiration elsewhere on the dial.
DMGI's competitors broker deals with independent labels for the right to sell the label's catalogue to the downloading services.
But DMGI is buying catalogues in addition to paying for the digital rights.
And it seems to be working.
Some of the labels DMGI own or partners with cut a wide swath through 20th century music.
Chancellor Records has historic tracks by Frankie Avalon, Fabian, and Johnny Rivers.
Turtle Island Records offers aboriginal and Native American music.
Compass Records specializes in Celtic music.
Biograph Records has a collection of historic American genres such as early jazz, ragtime, and blues.
And DMGI's recent buyout of a San Francisco-based aggregator adds contemporary artists, like Death Cab for Cutie, reggaeton superstar Daddy Yankee, and hip-hop star Ludicris.
Technology analyst Mike McGuire says DMGI has a good chance at success with labels like these, if they can continue to keep the cost down and keep their catalogue in digital circulation.
But, he adds, it's not without risk.
It's not a dead bang, no-brainer winner, as they say.
And then the gamble is that is this content that even though is niche, and there is the low-cost capability of distribution, can I find an audience for this?
And more importantly, can the audience find this work?
Wall Street is watching music aggregators, or at least DMGI.
Earlier this year, the company went public and generated enough revenue to make major acquisitions of even more catalogues.
Felix Contreras, NPR News.
No matter how much dramatic license the movie ""Defiance"" has taken, the story it was based on is dramatic enough in its own right.
It was the largest armed rescue of Jews by Jews during World War II.
Reporter Martha Wexler has been looking into what really happened.
This history played out in a region that was eastern Poland until 1939.
That year, it came under Soviet control until 1941, when the Germans moved in.
The SS soon began mass executions of Jews, including the Bielski parents, younger brothers and other family members.
That's when the older Bielski brothers, Tuvia, Asael, and Zus, took up arms and formed a detachment of Jewish partisans.
They helped other Jews escape the ghettos where the Germans had confined them.
This is portrayed in Edward Zwick's movie.
(Soundbite of movie ""Defiance"")
Unidentified Man #1: What if we take all of you?
Unidentified Man #2: The old, the sick?
There are thousands.
How will we live?
Unidentified Man #1: We will protect you.
The Bielskis kept moving their flock through the region's deep forest and inaccessible swamps, eluding the Germans and their collaborators.
Among those saved by the Bielskis was 14-year-old Jack Kagan.
The Germans had murdered his mother and sister along with 4,000 others in the town of Novogrudok.
In 1943, Jack took part in a hair-raising escape not depicted in the film, crawling through a tunnel the Jews had dug out of the town.

When I arrived to the camp, and I saw the two brothers, together with a reconnaissance party which came, probably another 12 or 15 riders, on tall horses, sitting with machine guns on the horses, for me it was an unbelievable sight, coming out from a camp, where there was starvation, with German guards continually punishing us, and coming out suddenly to freedom and to see the Jewish fighters.
By this point in the war, the Bielskis had built a veritable town in the forest, dubbed Jerusalem, with dug-out shelters and workshops, a bakery, sausage factory, a tannery.
By war's end, the Bielski group had sheltered 1,200 people, men, women, and children.
Of these, only 49 died due to enemy action - a phenomenal survival rate.
But beyond a tight circle of Holocaust survivors and former partisans, few people knew this story.
Enter sociologist and historian Nechama Tec.
In the 1980s, she was researching a book about another man who had saved many Jews during the Holocaust.
To check some facts, she phoned Tuvia Bielski, who was living out his last years in Brooklyn.
Professor Tec reminisced about that phone call as she addressed the audience after a recent screening of the new film.
He was very friendly and wanted to know what book I am writing, so I told him a little bit that this man saved 305 Jews.
He said big deal.
When you come to me, I will show you how people saved more than thousand people.
Tec went to meet Tuvia shortly before he died in 1987.

That interview, with dozens of others, formed the basis for her 1993 scholarly work ""Defiance: The Bielski Partisans."" She says she asked Tuvia why he took on the burden of so many Jews who could not fight.
He told her this.
The Germans kill everybody.
Good Jews, bad Jews, good Poles, bad Poles, everybody.
Who am I to imitate the Germans?
They kill, I save.
But to save so many lives, the Bielski fighters had to steal food from peasants in surrounding villages.
And they also killed, not only German soldiers, but local collaborators, as well.
The Jews were afraid to escape from the ghettos because the Poles would - and the Belarusians would, some, not all, they would deliver them to the enemy, to the Germans, and they would perish.
So, as Tec puts it, the Bielski fighters cleaned up the area.
You don't have to do it by many if you kill ten, if you destroy ten farms with the family and stuff, nobody is going to do it anymore.
The Bielski brothers also executed three fellow Jews for insubordination, but they succeeded not just because of their ruthless focus on mission.
They had survival skills that eluded many of the Jews they protected.
